text: Sadly, it wasn't until 45 years ago that the United States formally designated Black History Month.  The first celebration already had taken place, fittingly enough, at an educational institution, which was Kent State University, six years prior. Today, the influence of Black History Month enriches the curricula of schools, colleges, and universities throughout our nation, and it should lift the consciousness of all.  Its theme this year is Black Family Representation, Identity, and Diversity, exploring in part the strength of Black families across the United States. We don't have to look very far to find a deep personal appreciation and insight why its theme for 2021 so resonates and is so vital to our own school community.  In fact, we need look no further than Monticello High School. That's where Autumn King is a sophomore. For many years, Autumn was intrigued by an old family photo in her grandmother's house. It was of a young lady born in the latter half of the 19th century. Autumn often studied the picture, which was of a great, great, great grandmother.  a photo that immediately dominated her attention every time she entered the room where it was displayed. Autumn is an outstanding young woman who finds inspiration and guidance from the story of others in life and in art, just as she does every time she becomes reacquainted with that photo and its compelling image.  On the eve of Black History Month this year, with its focus on the strength of the Black family, Autumn's grandmother bestowed her with a very special gift. The photo, which has been passed down in the family for more than a century, now has been given to Autumn with the simple explanation, because I know its care will be in good hands.  Autumn has written about her great, great, great grandmother, not as a class assignment, but in response to an ancestor who has reached across several generations to speak to her. I'd like to ask Autumn to share her poem with us this evening. And Autumn, we are so glad that you're here with us.
speaker: jonnoalcaro

text: Hi, thank you for the introduction and thank you for having me. I'm really honored to be here.  Okay, so this poem is about my great, great, great grandmother Nancy and the picture of her when she was like, maybe around my age, maybe older. I'm not sure, but it's always inspired me. And this poem is called The Picture. A portrait of a Black woman lives above the bed in the last room of my grandparents' house. It's a fairly heirloom that my grandmother guards with pride.  The girl in the painting is a family member of mine. Her name is Nancy. And since I was a little girl, I've stared at this picture with eyes full of awe and curiosity. The picture was large and strangely round. Most of the pictures in the house were small, but this one was different. It looked straight out of the 19th century. The picture was hazy as if the camera was a foggy window. I've searched through it for any features that looked like mine.  The same nose slope, almond eyes, cheekbones, anything. The frame of the picture is the same color as my skin, and I'd wonder if it was the same as hers. Her world was covered in black and white, so I had to imagine it. Her face was masked in a frown, much like old pictures were. What did her smile look like? Eventually, I realized I didn't look like this picture.  But I still wondered if we had similar personalities. I questioned the tone of her voice. Was it as quiet and light like a feather? Or was it strong and moving as an ocean? How did she laugh? Was it a contagious laugh like my uncle's? Or was her laugh loud like mine? Eventually, a really scary question ran through my mind. Would she like me?  I was fascinated by this woman who was a part of me. And the idea that she wouldn't like me was terrifying. I look back and laugh about how I was worried about a woman in old picture liking me. Maybe my grandmother will pass this down to me and I can pass it on to future generations. I really hope she does. All right, that was it.

text: Yes, Chairman Page. I will start by reading the public comment guidelines. The school board invites and actively seeks the public's input in the matters relevant to school board governance and provides time during its business meetings to hear from Albemarle County residents and community members. The school board wishes to maintain appropriate meeting decorum so that persons can observe and hear the proceedings of the school board and that attendees online are not subject to inappropriate language and conduct.  As authorized by ordinance of the county of Albemarle, the school board will hold its meetings electronically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The school board is nevertheless committed to encouraging public comment, despite its need to meet on a virtual basis. For this reason, there'll be two ways for the public to provide comment. First, as always, written comments may be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting and will be given to all school board members for review.  You can also email the school board. And as long as the school board holds its meetings electronically, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the school board meeting may sign up online by 2pm the day of the meeting. Before electronic public comment starts, I'm going to announce the order. I'm actually going to do it three people at a time. We have 26 people signed up right now. So I'll do three people at a time. And then  Speakers will each have, I believe it's we lowered it to two minutes to speak and I will notify you when you have one minute left by holding up my finger. And hopefully all of you guys got that number. So you've been able to adjust accordingly.  Speakers during the meeting are those submitting written comments should state their name and address from magisterial district and speakers should limit comments to those matters that are relevant to school board governance or the operation of the school division. And lastly, although the school board will not respond to comments made during public comment during the public comment period, they may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business.  So with that, our first three speakers are going to be Michael Martinez, Laura Gonyar, and Pierre Padilla. So Michael, if you are on, it's your turn. I don't see him. Yeah, I'm not seeing him. So I will loop back at the end. Laura Gonyar, if you are on, you may go now.

text: Hello, my name is Laura Gonier. I am in the Rivanna district. In the fall, our lack of understanding on virus transmission and safety in schools led to a justified concern about in-person learning. Now we have data that schools are not a significant source of virus transmission and that the rigorous mitigation strategies in place are effective at keeping our children, teachers, and families safe. Also, an effective vaccine has been approved and has been offered  to ACPS teachers and staff as part of the early stages of vaccine rollout, highlighting how essential our schools are to the well-being of our community. Giving the choice for in-person learning to all families will allow our students a return to normalcy. My daughter has been participating in hybrid learning, and she is overjoyed on the days she is able to attend in-person with her friends and her amazing teacher.  I urge you to prioritize our students' academic success and mental health and to vote to move to stage four. Thank you.

text: Sorry about that. So hi, my name is Alana Smith. I live in the Scottsville district. I have five children who are all enrolled in Albemarle County Public Schools. I have one at Monticello, one at Walton Middle School, and three at Mountain View Elementary School. I have nothing but respect and admiration for everything that their amazing teachers are trying to do by educating them virtually right now, but I do not believe that the system is working. I believe it is way past time for them to return to school. Currently, my two teenagers do pretty much nothing but stare at screens all day long, and this is very unhealthy.  And they're not learning the material as well as they have in the past they are isolated and cut off from their friends their grades are suffering and this is not a good situation for them. My younger children are also struggling to retain the information they learned last year their reading levels have been dropping and honestly, as much as their teachers try really hard they hate doing zoom school. It's really sad to see their love of learning quashed when they're so young, but that's what's happening.  My youngest two have been able to go to school in person during stage three times and they're so happy when they get to go to school. It's wonderful to see, and I believe all children deserve this joy and success. I'm a stay at home mom with a master's degree and I'm able to help them a lot, but I really worry about all the children whose parents can't be there to help them. What is happening to those children?  Schools throughout the country, including Louisa County Augusta County flu Vanna County and nearly every private school in this area have managed to safely continue with in person learning during this pandemic, and there have not been mass outbreaks of coded. Honestly, there's no reason Albemarle County can't do this too.  This very school board recently determined that it was safe for high school students to participate in basketball wrestling cheer and swim. So I can't imagine why it would be more dangerous for children to sit and desk six feet apart with masks than it is for them to be wrestling. I think academics is much safer.  For parents who are uncomfortable with this, they can certainly continue to send their children to virtual school. I'm fine with that, but for those of us who have read the CDC guidelines and know that they said that the kids should be going back to school immediately, I believe it is time for us to exercise our constitutional right and have our children be in public education in school as soon as possible.
speaker: alannasmith

text: Good evening. My name is Vernon Lecti and I'm a teacher at Elmira High School. I want to applaud the school division for coordinating with the Blue Ridge Health Department to make vaccinations for ACPS staff possible. I'm also grateful that the school division has posted the total amount of staff and students that have had to quarantine since the 2021 school year began. Publishing this data gives us a great deal of information so that families can understand the risks involved  with in-person instruction. According to the dashboard, there have been 98 confirmed COVID cases among ACPS students, staff, and contractors who are learning or working in person. In addition, 287 students and staff have been forced to quarantine due to exposure to an individual with COVID at school or work. This is just the amount that we have recorded. This does not include the possible quarantining that parents, other family members, and non-school contacts may have had to do as well.
speaker: vernonliechti

text: Are the health metrics worse now than when the school board voted for stage three in the fall?
speaker: matthewhaas

text: Will the metrics be getting worse due to new variants of COVID that are spreading at a much more rapid rate? These same new variants, the current CDC director has stated, could reverse the recent drop in COVID cases and hospitalizations. I am encouraged by some of the safety metrics that ACPS is following, but I still feel that these safety metrics are lacking if our intention is to reduce the spread of COVID in our community. We have already had an outbreak in one of our schools.  Many other schools in the state have also experienced outbreaks. We still do not understand the long-term health effects of contracting COVID-19. According to the Mayo Clinic, COVID-19 has been linked to lasting organ damage in the heart, lungs, and brain. Is risking our lives and our life expectancy worth it? Please understand that currently reopening under stage four is a gamble. It is not a sure thing that there will be no outbreaks in schools. Your decision today will impact the health and safety of countless lives  And for many of us, the quality of life we will live, even after the COVID-19 pandemic has passed. I recommend the school board vote no on proceeding to stage four at this time. Thank you.

text: I am on, hi guys. So I wanted to start by saying thank you guys for hearing me out and letting me speak tonight. I wanted to start with, we can do better for our teachers, for our students, for our administrators, for our counselors and for our support staff. I'm speaking out actively against opening schools to phase four for three reasons.  One, disruption to the learning environment. School did not work for everybody either. Being in person didn't work for everybody either. It's time to adapt and think bigger. Two, the goal of as many teachers and potentially students getting vaccinated as possible  is also something I want to consider before going back. And three, the basis of the decision as it's currently being requested to be rolled out, in theory, is keeping the kids safe and better engaged, producing higher levels of equity, and establishing student-teacher connection. But in actuality, students will remain six feet apart, masked, and continue to learn from a teacher that has to stay glued to his or her computer screen.  Teachers and students deserve an advocate for their own mental health and sanity, because remember, we are in a pandemic. Teachers are suffering too. We are hurting, and we are feeling like we have no say, and not only going back into school without being fully vaccinated, without herd immunity, and without any recognition that we are doing a really good job in the situation we have been put in. And you know why? Because teachers love and respect their students.  We want to do right by them and keep them ahead of the curve, even when we are forced to adapt years of curriculum development into three weeks to virtual instruction. The idea of changing the schedule and environments of students and teachers with only three to four months of instruction left does not outweigh the stress and struggle of yet another change required of all members of this community. Content may have been lost this year, but stability has been found by more than we give credit.  The same students that we are wanting to reopen schools for the at-risk low income are the same kids that are saying they're not returning in phase four. Remember who we're fighting for here. Thank you, Ms. Dinwiddie.
speaker: annadinwiddie

text: Thank you. The next comment is gonna be from Katie Dougherty.

text: Hi, thank you for having me. My name is Katie Dougherty and I'm from the Whitehall District. text: Good evening, my name is Chris crater and i'm the CEO for a CAC fitness wellness centers and also the parent of two Western Albemarle high school students. You know I signed up to speak, because I think I can offer a couple of unique perspectives, one is a running a business that's been serving children. For the last year as a parent of students that are both full time in person and virtual and also as the husband of a teacher.  You know, first as a business we've been operating kids programs, including camp preschool and virtual learning support since May and operating our health club since June, and to all you who are members, we're happy to have you back. I understand firsthand how challenging it can be to manage the logistics of reopening.  and the implementation of new protocols needed to operate safely. I'm here to say that I believe in our schools and I also believe that they can move safely to stage four. I know it's not gonna be simple and there will be challenges, but I think it's time to offer the opportunity for all of our children to experience in-person learning. For my own kids, it'll have been a year since they've returned to the classroom. And I applaud the efforts that have been made to date to make virtual learning feasible by our teachers and support staff at Albemarle County Public Schools.  But from this parent's perspective, comparing both types of learning amongst my own kids, virtual is simply not an adequate replacement for in-person instruction. These kids are missing all those teachable moments that come throughout the school day that help round our children into the people they will become. I'm also concerned how long they've been on the screens, in front of their screens every day. The American Heart Association recommends only two hours a day, and I know they're on there for a lot longer than that every day of the school week.  I think this, coupled with what we know about the effects of isolation among our kids, I think virtual learning is going to create some significant long-term consequences for them.  You know, as I mentioned, my wife, Allie, is also a teacher, and after a few years away from teaching, she returned to Sears and working directly with a classroom of elementary kids since September. From firsthand experience with in-person learning, she can tell you that it has been needed and with proper precautions can be done safely. Albemarle County Schools, we can do this. I urge you to follow the science and move to stage four, and thank you for the opportunity to speak.

My husband next to me is a pulmonary critical care physician who's been on the front lines since the start of the pandemic a year ago. So together, we're very aware of the risks of COVID-19.  And we are also very aware of the element of fear that COVID-19 brings. At the beginning of the pandemic, I saw and examined many patients with COVID-19 with only a surgical mask because N95s were in short supply. My husband intubated patients in the ICU with COVID-19 wearing an N95 that he repeatedly sent to be sterilized and reused, despite not even knowing if that made the mask less effective.  We took out additional life insurance. We updated our wills. We were afraid one or both of us would be infected and terrified that our young children would be left orphaned. But despite this fear, we nonetheless kissed them goodbye every morning. We went to work every day and we served our communities. My message to you today is that we cannot allow fear to dictate decision making, particularly when that fear is unfounded based on scientific research available to us today.  There have been many studies based on real-life experience from summer camps, from schools in the United States, from abroad, all of which convincingly support that schools are not a significant source of community spread, and going back to school does not place our students or teachers at risk. I should note, vaccination was not available at the time of those studies, and therefore, while that's an important measure to take to ultimately end the pandemic, vaccination is not required for schools to safely reopen.  I coupled that with the data published by the CDC this week, demonstrating that double masking with a surgical mask and a cloth mask, both of which are inexpensive and widely available, is effective at blocking 92.5% of viral particles, which is an efficiency that nears that of the N95 that my husband and other healthcare workers wear when performing aerosol generating procedures on COVID positive patients. This information has led researchers at the CDC- Dr. Lawrence, your time is up.  Thank you, the American Academy of Pediatrics and many others. The same level of intervention. And critical support able to be given, and I understand that these teachers are going to do their best. I think we have a lot of very creative teachers. I think we have a lot of people who are passionate  about the work that they do, very good at it. But that math to me does not add up.  I support having students in schools if that's what their families need or want, but we also need to serve all of our students, and that also means the nearly half of our division students who have chosen to remain virtual. And we know that more of our students of color and our economically disadvantaged students are in that group, while more of their white and economically advantaged counterparts have chosen hybrid learning. So in order, in my opinion, to bring pre-K-3  students in four days a week, we're compounding the inequities that have plagued us for generations. I think that there is a simple fix for this. I feel like keeping our hybrid students at two days a week will help us preserve those intervention services, those ESOL services, and those specials  and we can help not deepen these inequities. I would also like to find a way to continue our meal delivery service in order to help not deepen these inequities. And for all these reasons, I can't vote for this plan as it is presented. But there's also another thing that I hope that we here on the board think about. I know that we all want to fight inequity. We all ran on it.  But we need to think about how can we, through our policy and governance, require accountability to all of our students? How can we ourselves be accountable? We're not the first ones who have wanted to fight inequity, and yet we find ourselves here.  So many times in these discussions in the past few months, we've been talking about health metrics, which I agree are very important, and I definitely have talked about them. But I want to know what metrics we can use to ensure that we've taught every student well in this time. We need to be thinking about that. We assume that in-person education is better, is it? How will we know that this version of it with partner teachers is better? And I think we need to be asking that of ourselves and of the division.
